title: Broken bone
paragraphs: Symptoms of a broken bone include:
lists: A visibly out-of-place or misshapen limb or joint
Limited mobility or inability to move a limb or put weight on the leg

title: Allergic reactions
paragraphs: Common symptoms of a mild allergic reaction include:
Symptoms of a moderate or severe reaction include:
lists: A few hives (especially over the neck and face)
Flushing or redness of the face
Swelling of the face, eyes, or tongue

title: Traumatic amputation
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
lists: Bleeding (may be minimal or severe, depending on the location and nature of the injury)
Pain (the degree of pain is not always related to the severity of the injury or the amount of bleeding)
Crushed body tissue (badly mangled, but still partially attached by muscle, bone, tendon, or skin)

title: Breathing difficulties - first aid
paragraphs: People having breathing difficulty will often look uncomfortable. They may be:
They might have other symptoms, including:
If an allergy is causing the breathing problem, they might have a rash or swelling of the face, tongue, or throat.
If an injury is causing breathing difficulty, they might be bleeding or have a visible wound.
lists: Unable to breathe lying down and need to sit up to breathe
Chest moving in an unusual way
Gurgling, wheezing, or making whistling sounds

title: Tailbone trauma
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists: Bruising on the lower part of the spine
Pain when sitting or putting pressure on the tailbone

title: CPR - infant
paragraphs: CPR should be done if the infant has the following symptoms:

title: CPR - young child (age 1 year to onset of puberty)
paragraphs: CPR should be done if the child has any of the following symptoms:

title: CPR - adult and child after onset of puberty
paragraphs: CPR should be done if a person has any of the following symptoms:

title: Dislocation
paragraphs: A dislocated joint may be:

Nursemaid's elbow, or pulled elbow, is a partial dislocation that is common in toddlers. The main symptom is pain so that the child doesn't want to use the arm. This dislocation can be easily treated in your provider's office.
lists: Accompanied by numbness or tingling at the joint or beyond it
Very painful, especially if you try to use the joint or put weight on it
Visibly out of place, discolored, or misshapen

title: Drug use first aid
paragraphs: Drug overdose symptoms vary widely, depending on the specific drug used, but may include:
Drug withdrawal symptoms also vary widely, depending on the specific drug used, but may include:
lists: Abnormal pupil size or pupils that don't change size when light is shined into them
Sweating or extremely dry, hot skin, blisters, rash

title: Smashed fingers
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
lists: Difficulty moving the tip of the finger
Discoloration or bruising of the finger or fingernail

title: Broken or dislocated jaw
paragraphs: Symptoms of a broken jaw include:
Symptoms of a dislocated jaw include:
lists: Pain in the face or jaw, located in front of the ear or on the affected side,Â that gets worse with movement
Bruising and swelling of the face, bleeding from the mouth
Jaw stiffness, difficulty opening the mouth widely, or problem closing the mouth
Jaw moving to one side when opening
Jaw tenderness or pain, worse with biting or chewing
Lump or abnormal appearance of the cheek or jaw
Numbness of the face (particularly the lower lip)
Pain in the face or jaw, located in front of the ear or on the affected side that gets worse with movement
Drooling because of inability to close the mouth
Locked jaw or jaw that protrudes forward
Teeth that do not line up properly

title: Unconsciousness - first aid
paragraphs: The person will be unresponsive (does not respond to activity, touch, sound, or other stimulation).
The following symptoms may occur after a person has been unconscious:
If the person is unconscious from choking, symptoms may include:
Being asleep is not the same as being unconscious. A sleeping person will respond to loud noises or gentle shaking. An unconscious person will not.
lists: Amnesia for (not remembering) events before, during, and even after the period of unconsciousness
Inability to speak or move parts of the body (stroke symptoms)
Loss of bowel or bladder control (incontinence)
Noisy breathing or high-pitched sounds while inhaling

title: Radiation sickness
paragraphs: Symptoms of radiation sickness may include:

Your health care provider will advise you how best to treat these symptoms. Medicines may be prescribed to help reduce nausea, vomiting, and pain. Blood transfusions may be given for anemiaÂ (low counts of healthy red blood cells). Antibiotics are used to prevent or fight infections.
lists: Bleeding from the nose, mouth, gums, and rectum
Bruising, skin burns, open sores on the skin, sloughing of skin
Inflammation of exposed areas (redness, tenderness, swelling, bleeding)
Nausea and vomiting, including vomiting of blood
Ulcers (sores) in the mouth, esophagus (food pipe), stomach or intestines

title: Poison ivy - oak - sumac rash
paragraphs: Symptoms include:

The reaction can vary from mild to severe. In rare cases, the person with the rash needs to be treated in the hospital. The worst symptoms are often seen during days 4 to 7 after coming in contact with the plant. The rash may last for 1 to 3 weeks.
lists: Red, streaky, patchy rash where the plant touched the skin
Red bumps, which may form large, weeping blisters

title: Head injury - first aid
paragraphs: Head injuries may cause bleeding in the brain tissue and the layers that surround the brain (subarachnoid hemorrhage, subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma).

Symptoms of a head injury can occur right away or may develop slowly over several hours or days. Even if the skull is not fractured, the brain can hit the inside of the skull and be bruised. The head may look fine, but problems could result from bleeding or swelling inside the skull.
The spinal cord is also likely to be injured from falls from a significant height or ejection from a vehicle.
Some head injuries cause changes in brain function. This is called a traumatic brain injury. A concussion is a type of traumatic brain injury. Symptoms of a concussion can range from mild to severe.

title: Spinal injury
paragraphs: Symptoms of a spinal cord injury may include any of the following:
lists: Head that is in an unusual position
Numbness or tingling that spreads down an arm or leg
Paralysis (loss of movement) of arms or legs
Loss of bladder or bowel control
Shock (pale, clammy skin, bluish lips and fingernails, acting dazed or semiconscious)
Stiff neck, headache, or neck pain

title: Burns
paragraphs: Burn symptoms can include:
You may have an airway burn if you have:
lists: Blisters that are either intact (unbroken)Â or have ruptured and are leaking fluid.
Pain -- How much pain you have is unrelated to the level of burn. The most serious burns can be painless.
ShockÂ -- Watch for pale and clammy skin, weakness, blue lips and fingernails, and a decrease in alertness.
Burns on the head, face, neck, eyebrows, or nose hairs

title: Snake bites
paragraphs: Symptoms depend on the type of snake, but may include:
Rattlesnake bites are painful when they occur. Symptoms usually begin right away and may include:
Cottonmouth and copperhead bites are painful right when they occur. Symptoms, which usually begin right away, may include:

Coral snake bites may be painless at first. Major symptoms may not develop for hours. Do not make the mistake of thinking you will be fine if the bite area looks good and you are not in a lot of pain. Untreated coral snake bites can be deadly. Symptoms may include:
lists: Swelling at the site of the bite
Pain and swelling at site of bite

title: Marine animal stings or bites
paragraphs: There may be pain, burning, swelling, redness, or bleeding near the area of the bite or sting. Other symptoms can affect the entire body, and may include:
lists: Unconsciousness or sudden death from heart rhythm irregularities

title: Insect bites and stings
paragraphs: Symptoms depend on the type of bite or sting. They may include:

Some people have severe, life-threatening allergic reactions to bee stings or insect bites. This is called anaphylactic shock. This condition can occur very quickly and lead to rapid death if not treated quickly.
Symptoms of anaphylaxis can occur quickly and affect the whole body. They include:

title: Foreign object - swallowed
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
Sometimes, only minor symptoms are seen at first. The object may be forgotten until symptoms such as inflammation or infection develop.
lists: No breathing or breathing trouble (respiratory distress)
Turning blue, red, or white in the face

title: Foreign body in the nose
paragraphs: Symptoms that your child may have a foreign body in his or her nose include:
lists: Difficulty breathing through the affected nostril
Feeling of something in the nose
Irritation or pain in the nose

title: Hypothermia
paragraphs: As a person develops hypothermia, they slowly lose the ability to think and move. In fact, they may even be unaware that they need emergency treatment. Someone with hypothermia also is likely to have frostbite.
The symptoms include:
Lethargy (weakness and sleepiness), cardiac arrest, shock, and coma can set in without prompt treatment. Hypothermia can be fatal.
lists: Shivering that cannot be controlled (although at extremely low body temperatures, shivering may stop)

title: Shock
paragraphs: A person in shock has extremely low blood pressure. Depending on the specific cause and type of shock, symptoms will include one or more of the following:

title: Sprains
paragraphs: Symptoms of a sprain include:
lists: Discoloration of the skin, especially bruising

title: Strains
paragraphs: Symptoms of a strain can include:
lists: Pain and difficulty moving the injured muscle

title: Cuts and puncture wounds
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
Infection may occur with some cuts and puncture wounds. The following are more likely to become infected:
lists: Problems with function (movement) or feeling (numbness, tingling) below the wound site
Wounds that are not promptly treated

title: Genital injury
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
lists: Change in shape of the affected area
Object embedded in a body opening
Groin pain or genital pain (can be extreme)
Urination that is painful or the inability to urinate

title: Bleeding
paragraphs: You may have symptoms such as:
Bleeding can also cause shock, which may include any of the following symptoms:
Symptoms of internal bleeding may include those listed above for shock as well as the following:
Blood coming from a natural opening in the body may also be a sign of internal bleeding. These symptoms include:
lists: Blood coming from an open wound
Dizziness or light headedness after an injury
Blood in the stool (appears black, maroon, or bright red)
Blood in the urine (appears red, pink, or tea-colored)
Blood in the vomit (looks bright red, or brown like coffee-grounds)
Vaginal bleeding (heavier than usual or after menopause)

title: Non-fatal drowning
paragraphs: Symptoms can vary, but may include:
lists: Bluish skin of the face, especially around the lips

title: Choking - infant under 1 year
paragraphs: The danger signs of choking are:
lists: Difficulty breathing -- ribs and chest pull inward
Loss of consciousness (unresponsiveness) if blockage is not cleared
Inability to cry or make much sound
Soft or high-pitched sounds while inhaling

title: Choking - adult or child over 1 year
paragraphs: When an older child or adult is choking, they will often grab their throat with the hand. If the person does not do this, look for these danger signs:
lists: Noisy breathing or high-pitched sounds while inhaling
Loss of consciousness (unresponsiveness) if blockage is not cleared

title: Choking - unconscious adult or child over 1 year
paragraphs: Symptoms of choking when a person is unconscious include:
lists: Bluish color to the lips and nails (cyanosis)

title: Ear emergencies
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists: Clear liquid coming out of the ear (brain fluid also called cerebrospinal fluid)
Sensations of an object in the ear

title: Electrical injury
paragraphs: Symptoms depend on many things, including:
Symptoms may include:
lists: How long you were in contact with the electricity
How the electricity moved through your body
Heart attack (chest, arm, neck, jaw, or back pain)
Problems with swallowing, vision, or hearing

title: Eye emergencies
paragraphs: Depending on the type of injury, any of the following symptoms may be present:
lists: Bleeding or other discharge from or around the eye
Loss of vision, total or partial, one eye or bothÂ
Sensation of something in the eye
Stinging or burning in the eye

title: Fishhook removal
paragraphs: A fishhook stuck in the skin can cause:

title: Heat emergencies
paragraphs: Muscle cramps are the first stage of heat illness. If heat exposure continues and these symptoms are not treated, they can lead to heat exhaustion and then heat stroke.
Heat stroke occurs when the body is no longer able to regulate its temperature, and it keeps rising. Heat stroke can cause shock, brain damage, organ failure, and even death.
The early symptoms of heat illness include:
Later symptoms of heat exhaustion include:
The symptoms of heatstroke include those of heat exhaustion in combination with very high body temperature and significant neurologic symptoms (call 911 or the local emergency number right away):
lists: Muscle cramps and pains that most often occur in the legs or abdomen, and may be due to multiple factors including exercising in the heat.

title: Frostbite
paragraphs: Symptoms of frostbite may include:
Very severe frostbite may cause:
Frostbite may affect any part of the body. The hands, feet, nose, and ears are the places most prone to frostbite.
lists: Pins and needles feeling, followed by numbness
Hard, pale, and cold skin that has been exposed to the cold for too long
Aching, throbbing or lack of feeling in the affected area
Red and extremely painful skin and muscle as the area thaws
Damage to tendons, muscles, nerves, and bone
If the frostbite did not affect your blood vessels, a complete recovery is possible.
If the frostbite affected the blood vessels, the damage is permanent. Gangrene may occur. This may require removal of the affected body part (amputation).

title: Chemical burn or reaction
paragraphs: Depending on the type of exposure, the symptoms may include:
lists: Bright red or bluish skin and lips
Hives, itching, swelling, or weakness resulting from an allergic reaction
Pain where the skin has come in contact with the toxic substance
Rash, blisters, burns on the skin
Unconsciousness or other states of altered level of consciousness

title: Skull fracture
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
In some cases, the only symptom may be a bump on the head. A bump or bruise may take up to 24 hours to develop.
lists: Bleeding from wound, ears, nose, or around eyes
Bruising behind the ears or under the eyes
Changes in pupils (sizes unequal, not reactive to light)
Drainage of clear or bloody fluid from ears or nose

title: Nose fracture
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
The bruised appearance most often disappears after 2 weeks.
lists: Misshapen appearance (may not be apparent until the swelling goes down)

title: Heart attack first aid
paragraphs: Symptoms of a heart attack can vary from person to person. They may be mild or severe. Women, older adults, and people with diabetes are more likely to have subtle or unusual symptoms.
Symptoms in adults may include:
lists: Changes in mental status, especially in older adults.

Chest pain that feels like pressure, squeezing, or fullness. The pain is most often in the center of the chest. It may also be felt in the jaw, shoulder, arms, back, and stomach. It can last for more than a few minutes, or come and go.
Numbness, aching, or tingling in the arm (usually the left arm, but the right arm may be affected alone, or along with the left).
Weakness or fatigue, especially in older adults and in women.

title: Sleep disorders in older adults
paragraphs: Symptoms that may occur include:
lists: Difficulty telling the difference between night and day
Waking up often during the night (for example, due to nocturia)

title: Atelectasis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
There are no symptoms if atelectasis is mild.

title: Blockage of upper airway
paragraphs: Symptoms vary, depending on the cause. But some symptoms are common to all types of airway blockage. These include:
lists: Difficulty breathing, gasping for air, leading to panic
Wheezing, crowing, whistling, or other unusual breathing noises indicating breathing difficulty

title: Histiocytosis
paragraphs: Both Langerhans cell histiocytosis and Erdheim-Chester disease can affect the whole body (systemic disorder).

Symptoms can vary between children and adults, but they may have some of the same symptoms. Tumors in weight-bearing bones, such as the legs or spine, may cause the bones to fracture without an obvious reason.
Symptoms in children may include:
Note: Children over 5 years old often have only bone involvement.
Symptoms in adults may include:
lists: Eyes that appear to stick out more and more
Thirst and increased drinking of fluids
General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling
Thirst and increased drinking of fluids

title: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
paragraphs: When you have IPF, your lungs become scarred and stiffened. This makes it hard for you to breathe. In most people, IPF gets worse quickly over months or a few years. In others, IPF worsens over a much longer time.
Symptoms may include any of the following:
lists: Not able to be as active as before
Shortness of breath during activity (this symptom lasts for months or years, and over time may also occur when at rest)

title: Solitary pulmonary nodule
paragraphs: A solitary pulmonary nodule itself rarely causes symptoms.

title: Industrial bronchitis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:

title: Viral pneumonia
paragraphs: Symptoms of viral pneumonia often begin slowly and may not be severe at first.
The most common symptoms of pneumonia are:
Other symptoms include:
lists: Cough (with some pneumonias you may cough up mucus, or even bloody mucus)
Shortness of breath (may only occur when you exert yourself)
Loss of appetite, low energy, and fatigue
Sharp or stabbing chest pain that gets worse when you breathe deeply or cough

title: Pulmonary actinomycosis
paragraphs: The infection often comes on slowly. It may be weeks or months before diagnosis is confirmed.
Symptoms may include any of the following:
lists: Chest pain when taking a deep breath

title: Pulmonary veno-occlusive disease
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:

title: Sarcoidosis
paragraphs: There may be no symptoms. When symptoms do occur, they can involve almost any body part or organ system.
Almost all people affected by sarcoidosis have lung or chest symptoms:
Symptoms of general discomfort may include:
Skin symptoms may include:
Nervous system symptoms may include:
Eye symptoms may include:
Other symptoms of this disease may include:
lists: Chest pain (most often behind the breast bone)
Raised, red, firm skin sores (erythema nodosum), almost always on the front part of the lower legs
Scars that become raised or inflamed
Weakness on one side of the face
Burning, itching, discharge from the eye
Fainting spells, if the heart is involved
Swelling in the upper part of the abdomen
Swelling of the legs if heart and lungs are involved
Abnormal heart rhythm if the heart is involved

title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
paragraphs: The primary stage of TB does not cause symptoms. When symptoms of pulmonary TB occur, they can include:

title: Primary alveolar hypoventilation
paragraphs: Symptoms are usually worse during sleep. Episodes of stopped breathing (apnea) often occur while sleeping. Often there is no shortness of breath during the day.
Symptoms include:
People with this disease are very sensitive to even small doses of sedatives or narcotics. These drugs can make their breathing problem much worse.
lists: Bluish coloration of the skin caused by lack of oxygen (cyanosis)
Waking up many times at night

title: Atypical pneumonia
paragraphs: Pneumonia due to mycoplasma and chlamydophila bacteria is usually mild. Pneumonia due to legionella gets worse during the first 4 to 6 days, and then improves over 4 to 5 days.
The most common symptoms of pneumonia are:
Other symptoms include:
Less common symptoms include:
lists: Cough (with legionella pneumonia, you may cough up bloody mucus)
Fever, which may be mild or high
Shortness of breath (may only occur when you exert yourself)
Chest pain that gets worse when you breathe deeply or cough
Confusion, most often in older people or those with legionella pneumonia
Loss of appetite, low energy, and fatigue
Eye pain or soreness (with mycoplasma pneumonia)

title: Flu
paragraphs: Flu symptoms often start quickly. You can start to feel sick about 1 to 7 days after you come in contact with the virus. Most of the time, symptoms appear within 2 to 3 days.
The first symptom is often a fever between 100Â°F (37.8Â°C) and 104Â°F (40Â°C) that comes on suddenly. An adult often has a lower fever than a child. But not everyone with the flu has a fever.
Other common symptoms include:
Fever usually goes away in 3 to 4 days but may last up to 8 days. Other symptoms get better in 7 to 14 days. The cough and tired feeling may last for weeks. Sometimes, the fever comes back.
Some people may not feel like eating.
The flu can make asthma, breathing problems, and other long-term (chronic) illnesses and conditions worse.
lists: Nausea, vomiting and diarrhea (more common in children)

title: Mediastinitis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
Signs of mediastinitis in people who have had recent surgery include:

title: Mycoplasma pneumonia
paragraphs: Symptoms are often mild and appear over 1 to 3 weeks. They may become more severe in some people.
Common symptoms include any of the following:
Less common symptoms include:
lists: Cough, usually dry and not bloody

title: Pulmonary nocardiosis
paragraphs: Pulmonary nocardiosis mainly affects the lungs. But, nocardiosis can also spread to other organs in the body. Common symptoms may include:
ENTIRE BODY
GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM
LUNGS AND AIRWAYS
MUSCLES AND JOINTS
NERVOUS SYSTEM
SKIN
lists: Chest pain not due to heart problems

title: Pneumomediastinum
paragraphs: There may be no symptoms. The condition usually causes chest pain behind the breastbone, which may spread to the neck or arms. The pain may be worse when you take a breath or swallow.

title: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS)
paragraphs: The main symptoms of OHS are due to lack of sleep and include:
Symptoms of low blood oxygen level (chronic hypoxia) and high carbon dioxide can occur. Symptoms include shortness of breath or feeling tired after little effort.

title: Pleural effusion
paragraphs: Symptoms can include any of the following:
Sometimes there are no symptoms.
lists: Chest pain, usually a sharp pain that is worse with cough or deep breaths

title: Collapsed lung (pneumothorax)
paragraphs: Common symptoms of a collapsed lung include:
A larger pneumothorax causes more severe symptoms, including:
lists: Sharp chest or shoulder pain, made worse by a deep breath or a cough
Bluish color of the skin due to lack of oxygen
Abnormal breathing patterns or increased effort of breathing

title: Psittacosis
paragraphs: The incubation period of psittacosis is 5 to 15 days. The incubation period is the time it takes for symptoms to appear after being exposed to the bacteria.
Symptoms may include:
lists: Muscle aches (most often in the head and neck)
Swelling in the back of the throat (pharyngitis)

title: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
Because the symptoms develop slowly, many people may not know that they have COPD.
lists: Shortness of breath (dyspnea) that gets worse with mild activity

title: Respiratory acidosis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:

title: Pneumonia - weakened immune system
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
Other symptoms that may occur:
lists: Cough (may be dry or produce mucus-like, greenish, or pus-like sputum)
General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise)
Sharp or stabbing chest pain that gets worse with deep breathing or coughing

title: Lung metastases
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:

title: Histoplasmosis - acute (primary) pulmonary
paragraphs: Most people with acute pulmonary histoplasmosis have no symptoms or only mild symptoms. The most common symptoms are:
Acute pulmonary histoplasmosis can be a serious illness in the very young, older people, and people with a weakened immune system, including those who:
Symptoms in these people may include:
lists: Rash (usually small sores on the lower legs)
Have had bone marrow or solid organ transplants
Take medicines that suppress their immune system

title: Blastomycosis
paragraphs: Lung infection may not cause any symptoms. Symptoms may be seen if the infection spreads. Symptoms may include:
Most people develop skin symptoms when the infection spreads. You may get papules, pustules, or nodules on exposed body areas.
The pustules:
lists: Cough (may produce brown or bloody mucus)
General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise)
May look like warts or ulcers
Vary in color from gray to violet
May appear in the nose and mouth

title: Acute respiratory distress syndrome
paragraphs: Symptoms usually develop within 24 to 48 hours of the injury or illness. Often, people with ARDS are so sick they cannot report symptoms. Symptoms can include any of the following:
lists: Low blood pressure and organ failure

title: Drug-induced pulmonary disease
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:

title: Simple pulmonary eosinophilia
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
Symptoms can range from none at all to severe. They may go away without treatment.

title: Cystic fibrosis
paragraphs: Symptoms in newborns may include:
Symptoms related to bowel function may include:
Symptoms related to the lungs and sinuses may include:
Symptoms that may be noticed later in life:
lists: Failure to gain weight normally during childhood
No bowel movements in first 24 to 48 hours of life
Increased gas, bloating, or a belly that appears swollen (distended)
Stools that are pale or clay-colored, foul smelling, have mucus, or that float
Coughing or increased mucus in the sinuses or lungs
Nasal congestion caused by nasal polyps
Repeated episodes of pneumonia (symptoms of pneumonia in someone with cystic fibrosis include fever, increased coughing and shortness of breath, increased mucus, and loss of appetite)
Sinus pain or pressure caused by infection or polyps

title: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
paragraphs: Symptoms often occur 4 to 8 hours after you have left the area where the triggering substance is found. This makes it hard to figure out what has caused the disease. Your symptoms may get better before you go back to the area where you were exposed to the substance. In the chronic phase of the condition, the symptoms are more constant and less affected by exposure to the substance.
Symptoms after acute exposure may include:
Symptoms of chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis may include:

title: Occupational asthma
paragraphs: Symptoms are usually due toÂ narrowing of the airways and tightening spasms of the muscles lining the airways. This reduces the amount of air that can pass through, which can lead to wheezing sounds.

Symptoms usually occur shortly after you are exposed to the substance. They often improve or go away when you leave work. Some people may not have symptoms until 12 or more hours after being exposed to the trigger.
Symptoms usually get worse toward the end of the work week and may go away on weekends or vacations.
Symptoms include:

title: Respiratory alkalosis
paragraphs: The symptoms may include:
lists: Numbness of the hands and feet

title: Pulmonary hypertension
paragraphs: Shortness of breath or lightheadedness during activity is often the first symptom. Fast heart rate (palpitations) may be present. Over time, symptoms occur with lighter activity or even while at rest.
Other symptoms include:
People with pulmonary hypertension often have symptoms that come and go. They report good days and bad days.
lists: Bluish color of the lips or skin (cyanosis)
Chest pain or pressure, most often in the front of the chest
Increased abdominal size due to fluid buildup

title: Rheumatoid lung disease
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:

title: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
paragraphs: Symptoms of PAP may include any of the following:
Sometimes, there are no symptoms.
lists: Fever, if there is lung infection

title: Malignant mesothelioma
paragraphs: Symptoms may not appear until 20 to 40 years or longer after exposure to asbestos, and may include:
lists: Chest pain, especially when taking a deep breath

title: Solitary fibrous tumor
paragraphs: About one half of the people with this type of tumor do not show any symptoms.
If the tumor grows to a large size and pushes on the lung, it can lead to symptoms, such as:

title: Metastatic pleural tumor
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
lists: Chest pain, especially when taking a deep breath
General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise)

title: Asbestosis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
Possible other symptoms include:
lists: Shortness of breath with activity (slowly gets worse over time)

title: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
lists: Shortness of breath with and without exertion, and other symptoms of COPD

title: Aspiration pneumonia
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
lists: Coughing up foul-smelling, greenish or dark phlegm (sputum), or phlegm that contains pus or blood
Seeing food or tube feed material (if being fed artificially) in your sputum

title: Lung cancer - small cell
paragraphs: Symptoms of SCLC include:
Other symptoms that may occur with this disease, especially in the late stages, include:

title: Empyema
paragraphs: Symptoms of empyema may include any of the following:
lists: Chest pain, which worsens when you breathe in deeply (pleurisy)
General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise)

title: Hemothorax
paragraphs: Symptoms include:

title: Pulmonary aspergilloma
paragraphs: You may not have symptoms. When symptoms do develop, they can include:
lists: Coughing up blood, which can be a life-threatening sign

title: Interstitial lung disease
paragraphs: Shortness of breath is a main symptom of ILD. You may breathe faster or need to take deep breaths:
Most people with this condition also have a dry cough. A dry cough means you do not cough up any mucus or sputum.
Over time, weight loss, fatigue, and muscle and joint pain are also present.
People with more advanced ILD may have:
lists: At first, shortness of breath may not be severe and is only noticed with exercise, climbing stairs, and other activities.
Over time, it can occur with less strenuous activity such as bathing or dressing, and as the disease worsens, even with eating or talking.
Abnormal enlargement and curving of the base of the fingernails (clubbing).
Blue color of the lips, skin, or fingernails due to low blood oxygen levels (cyanosis).
Symptoms of the other diseases such as arthritis or trouble swallowing (scleroderma), associated with ILD.

title: Cor pulmonale
paragraphs: Shortness of breath or lightheadedness during activity is often the first symptom of cor pulmonale. You may also have a fast heartbeat and feel like your heart is pounding.
Over time, symptoms occur with lighter activity or even while you are at rest. Symptoms you may have are:
lists: Chest discomfort, usually in the front of the chest
Swelling of the feet or ankles
Symptoms of lung disorders, such as wheezing or coughing or phlegm production

title: Coal worker's pneumoconiosis
paragraphs: Symptoms of CWP include:

title: Pulmonary embolus
paragraphs: The main symptoms of a pulmonary embolism include chest pain that may be any of the following:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Under the breastbone or on one side
Burning, aching, or a dull, heavy sensation
Often gets worse with deep breathing
You may bend over or hold your chest in response to the pain
Sudden cough, possibly coughing up blood or bloody mucus
Shortness of breath that starts suddenly during sleep or on exertion

title: Acute mountain sickness
paragraphs: Your symptoms will also depend on the speed of your climb and how hard you push (exert) yourself. Symptoms range from mild to life-threatening. They can affect the nervous system, lungs, muscles, and heart.
In most cases, symptoms are mild. Symptoms of mild to moderate acute mountain sickness may include:
Symptoms that may occur with more severe acute mountain sickness include the following and may progress to high altitude pulmonary edema or high altitude cerebral edema:
lists: Decreased consciousness or withdrawal from social interaction
Inability to walk in a straight line, or walk at all

title: Silicosis
paragraphs: Symptoms include:

title: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
paragraphs: Frequent sinusitis and bloody noses are the most common symptoms. Other early symptoms include a fever that has no clear cause, night sweats, fatigue, and a general ill feeling (malaise).
Other common symptoms may include:
Less common symptoms include:
lists: Pain, and sores around the opening of the nose
Cough with or without blood in the sputum
Chest pain and shortness of breath as the disease progresses
Loss of appetite and weight loss
Skin changes such as bruises and ulcers of the skin
Eye problems ranging from mild conjunctivitis to severe swelling of the eye

title: Rheumatoid pneumoconiosis
paragraphs: Symptoms of RP are:

title: Parapneumonic pleural effusion
paragraphs: Symptoms can include any of the following:
lists: Chest pain, usually a sharp pain that is worse with cough or deep breaths

title: Pulmonary edema
paragraphs: Symptoms of pulmonary edema may include:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Coughing up blood or bloody froth
Feeling of "air hunger" or "drowning" (This feeling is called "paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea" if it causes you to wake up 1 to 2 hours after falling asleep and struggle to catch your breath.)
Grunting, gurgling, or wheezing sounds with breathing
Problems speaking in full sentences because of shortness of breath

title: Asthma
paragraphs: Asthma symptoms vary from person to person. For example, you may have symptoms all the time or mostly during physical activity.

Most people with asthma have attacks separated by symptom-free periods. Some people have long-term shortness of breath with episodes of increased shortness of breath. Wheezing or a cough may be the main symptom.
Asthma attacks can last for minutes to days. An asthma attack may start suddenly or develop slowly over several hours or days. It may become dangerous if airflow is severely blocked.
Symptoms of asthma include:
Emergency symptoms that need prompt medical help include:
lists: Cough with or without sputum (phlegm) production
Pulling in of the skin between the ribs when breathing (intercostal retractions)
Shortness of breath that gets worse with exercise or activity
Whistling sound or wheezing as you breathe
Pain or tightness in the chest
Abnormal breathing pattern (breathing out takes more than twice as long as breathing in)
Bluish color to the lips and face (cyanosis)
Decreased level of alertness, such as severe drowsiness or confusion, during an asthma attack
Severe anxiety due to shortness of breath

title: Anti-glomerular basement membrane disease
paragraphs: Symptoms may occur very slowly over months or even years, but they often develop very quickly over days to weeks.
Loss of appetite, fatigue, and weakness are common early symptoms.
Lung symptoms may include:
Kidney and other symptoms include:
lists: Swelling (edema) in any area of the body, especially in the legs

title: Chemical pneumonitis
paragraphs: Acute symptoms may include:
Chronic symptoms may include:
lists: Air hunger (feeling that you cannot get enough air)
Breathing that soundsÂ wet or gurgling (abnormal lung sounds)
Unusual sensation (possibly burning feeling) in the chest
Progressive disability (related to shortness of breath)
Shortness of breath with only mild exercise

title: Bronchiectasis
paragraphs: Symptoms develop over time. They may occur months or years after the event that causes the bronchiectasis.
Long-term (chronic) cough with large amounts of foul smelling sputum is the main symptom of bronchiectasis. Other symptoms may include:
lists: Coughing up blood (less common in children)
Shortness of breath that gets worse with exercise
Low grade fever and night sweats
Clubbing of fingers (rare, depends on cause)

title: Community-acquired pneumonia in adults
paragraphs: The most common symptoms of pneumonia are:
Other symptoms include:
lists: Cough (with some pneumonias you may cough up greenish or yellow mucus, or even bloody mucus)
Fever, which may be mild or high
Shortness of breath (may only occur when you climb stairs or exert yourself)
Loss of appetite, low energy, and fatigue
Sharp or stabbing chest pain that gets worse when you breathe deeply or cough

title: Hospital-acquired pneumonia
paragraphs: In older adults, the first sign of hospital-acquired pneumonia may be mental changes or confusion.
Other symptoms may include:
lists: A cough with greenish or pus-like phlegm (sputum)
General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise)
Sharp chest pain that gets worse with deep breathing or coughing

title: Cystic hygroma
paragraphs: A common symptom is a neck growth. It may be found at birth, or discovered later in an infant after an upper respiratory tract infection (such as a cold).

title: Myocarditis
paragraphs: There may be no symptoms. Symptoms may be similar to the flu. If symptoms occur, they may include:
Other symptoms that may occur with this disease include:
lists: Chest pain that may resemble a heart attack
Fever and other signs of infection including headache, muscle aches, sore throat, diarrhea, or rashes
Pale, cool hands and feet (a sign of poor circulation)
Fainting, often related to irregular heart rhythms

title: Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
paragraphs: Symptoms of KTS include:
Other possible symptoms:
lists: Many port wine stains or other blood vessel problems, including dark spots on the skin
Varicose veins (may be seen in early infancy, but are more likely to be seen later in childhood or adolescence)
Unstable gait due to limb-length difference (involved limb is longer)

title: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW)
paragraphs: How often a rapid heart rate occurs varies depending on the person. Some people with WPW syndrome have only a few episodes of rapid heart rate. Others may have the rapid heart rate once or twice a week or more. Also, there may be no symptoms at all, so that condition is found when a heart test is done for another reason.
A person with this syndrome may have:
lists: Palpitations (a sensation of feeling your heart beating, usually quickly or irregularly)

title: Deep vein thrombosis
paragraphs: DVT mainly affects the large veins in the lower leg and thigh, most often on one side of the body. The clot can block blood flow and cause:
lists: Skin that feels warm to the touch
Swelling (edema) of a leg or arm
Pain or tenderness in a leg or arm

title: Atrial septal defect (ASD)
paragraphs: A person with no other heart defect, or a small defect (less than 5 millimeters) may not have any symptoms, or symptoms may not occur until middle age or later.
Symptoms that do occur may begin at any time after birth through childhood. They can include:
lists: Feeling the heart beat (palpitations) in adults

title: Heart failure
paragraphs: Symptoms of heart failure often begin slowly. At first, they may only occur when you are very active. Over time, you may notice breathing problems and other symptoms even when you are resting. Symptoms may also appear suddenly after the heart is damaged from a heart attack or other problem.
Common symptoms are:
lists: Pulse that feels fast or irregular, or a sensation of feeling the heartbeat (palpitations)
Shortness of breath when you are active or after you lie down
Waking up from sleep after a couple of hours due to shortness of breath

title: Coronary artery spasm
paragraphs: Spasm may be "silent" (without symptoms) or it may result in chest pain or angina. If the spasm lasts long enough, it may even cause a heart attack.
The main symptom is a type of chest pain called angina. Typically, the chest pain feels like tightness, heavy pressure, squeezing, or a crushing feeling. It may spread to the:
Some people say the pain feels like gas or indigestion. It is most often severe. The pain may spread to the neck, jaw, shoulder, or arm.
The pain of coronary artery spasm:
The person may lose consciousness.
Chest pain and shortness of breath due to coronary artery spasm are often not caused by exercise, unlike angina that is caused by hardening of the coronary arteries.
lists: May occur at the same time each day, usually between midnight and 8:00 a.m.

title: Sick sinus syndrome
paragraphs: Most of the time, there are no symptoms.
Symptoms that do occur may mimic those of other disorders.
Symptoms may include:
lists: Confusion or other changes in mental status
Sensation of feeling the heart beat (palpitations)
Shortness of breath, possibly only with physical activity like walking

title: Abdominal aortic aneurysm
paragraphs: Aneurysms can develop slowly over many years, often with no symptoms. Symptoms may come on quickly if the aneurysm expands rapidly, tears open or leaks blood within the wall of the vessel (aortic dissection).
Symptoms of rupture include:
lists: Pain in the abdomen or back. The pain may be severe, sudden, persistent, or constant. It may spread to the groin, buttocks, or legs.

title: Costochondritis
paragraphs: The most common symptoms of costochondritis are pain and tenderness in the chest. You may feel:
lists: Sharp pain at the front of your chest wall, which may move to your back or stomach
Increased pain when you take a deep breath or cough
Tenderness when you press the area where the rib joins the breastbone
Less pain when you stop moving and breathe quietly

title: Digitalis toxicity
paragraphs: These are symptoms of digitalis toxicity:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Vision changes (unusual), including blind spots, blurred vision, changes in how colors look, or seeing spots

title: Pericarditis - after heart attack
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists: Chest pain from the swollen pericardium rubbing on the heart. The pain may be sharp, tight or crushing and may move to the neck, shoulder, or abdomen. The pain may also be worse when you breathe and go away when you lean forward, stand, or sit up.
Fever (common with the second type of pericarditis)
Splinting of ribs (bending over or holding the chest) with deep breathing

title: Hypovolemic shock
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
The greater and more rapid the blood loss, the more severe the symptoms of shock.

title: Dilated cardiomyopathy
paragraphs: Symptoms of heart failure are most common. They most often develop slowly over time. However, sometimes symptoms start very suddenly and may be severe.
Common symptoms are:
lists: Chest pain or pressure (more likely with exercise)
Shortness of breath with activity or after lying down (or being asleep) for a while

title: Tricuspid regurgitation
paragraphs: Mild tricuspid regurgitation may not cause any symptoms. Symptoms of heart failure may occur, and can include:
lists: Active pulsing in the neck veins
Swelling of the feet and ankles

title: Peripheral artery disease - legs
paragraphs: The main symptoms of PAD are pain, achiness, fatigue, burning, or discomfort in the muscles of your feet, calves, or thighs. These symptoms most often appear during walking or exercise, and go away after several minutes of rest.
When PAD becomes severe, you may have:
lists: At first, these symptoms may appear only when you walk uphill, walk faster, or walk for longer distances.
Over time, these symptoms occur more quickly and with less exercise.
Your legs or feet may feel numb when you are at rest. The legs also may feel cool to the touch, and the skin may look pale.
Pain or tingling in the feet or toes, which can be so severe that even the weight of clothes or bed sheets is painful
Pain that is worse when you elevate your legs, and improves when you dangle your legs over the side of the bed
Skin that looks dark and blue

title: Atherosclerosis
paragraphs: Atherosclerosis does not cause symptoms until blood flow to part of the body becomes slowed or blocked.
If the arteries supplying the heart become narrow, blood flow can slow down or stop. This can cause chest pain (stable angina), shortness of breath, and other symptoms.
Narrowed or blocked arteries may also cause problems in the intestines, kidneys, legs, and brain.

title: Thromboangiitis obliterans
paragraphs: Symptoms most often affect 2 or more limbs and may include:
lists: Fingers or toes that appear pale, red, or bluish and feel cold to the touch.
Sudden severe pain in the hands and feet. The pain may feel like a burning or tingling sensation.
Pain in the hands and feet that most often occurs when at rest. The pain may be worse when the hands and feet get cold or during emotional stress.
Pain in the legs, ankles, or feet when walking (intermittent claudication). The pain is often located in the arch of the foot.
Skin changes or small painful ulcers on the fingers or toes.
Occasionally, arthritis in the wrists or knees develops before the blood vessels become blocked.

title: Mitral stenosis
paragraphs: Adults may have no symptoms. However, symptoms may appear or get worse with exercise or other activity that raises the heart rate. Symptoms will most often develop between ages 20 and 50.

Symptoms may begin with an episode of atrial fibrillation (especially if it causes a fast heart rate). Symptoms may also be triggered by pregnancy or other stress on the body, such as infection in the heart or lungs, or other heart disorders.
Symptoms may include:
In infants and children, symptoms may be present from birth (congenital). They will almost always develop within the first 2 years of life. Symptoms include:
lists: Chest discomfort that increases with activity and extends to the arm, neck, jaw or other areas (this is rare)
Difficulty breathing during or after exercise (This is the most common symptom.)
Waking up due to breathing problems or when lying in a flat position
Frequent respiratory infections, such as bronchitis
Poor feeding, or sweating when feeding

title: Mitral valve regurgitation
paragraphs: Symptoms may begin suddenly if:
There are often no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they often develop gradually, and may include:
lists: A heart attack damages the muscles around the mitral valve.
The cords that attach the muscle to the valve break.
An infection of the valve destroys part of the valve.
Sensation of feeling the heart beat (palpitations) or a rapid heartbeat
Shortness of breath that increases with activity and when lying down
Waking up an hour or so after falling asleep because of trouble breathing

title: Aortic stenosis
paragraphs: Most people with aortic stenosis do not develop symptoms until the disease is advanced. The diagnosis may have been made when the health care provider heard a heart murmur and performed tests before any symptoms developed.
Symptoms of aortic stenosis include:
In infants and children, symptoms include:
Children with mild or moderate aortic stenosis may get worse as they get older. They are also at risk for a heart infection called bacterial endocarditis.
lists: Chest discomfort: The chest pain may get worse with activity and reach into the arm, neck, or jaw. The chest may also feel tight or squeezed.
Fainting, weakness, or dizziness with activity.
Becoming easily tired with exertion (in mild cases)
Serious breathing problems that develop within days or weeks of birth (in severe cases)

title: Aortic regurgitation
paragraphs: The condition often has no symptoms for many years. Symptoms may come on slowly or suddenly. They may include:
lists: Shortness of breath with activity or when lying down
Waking up short of breath after falling asleep
Swelling of the feet, legs, or abdomen
Uneven, rapid, racing, pounding, or fluttering pulse
Weakness that is more likely to occur with activity

title: Mitral valve prolapse
paragraphs: Many people with mitral valve prolapse Do not have symptoms. A group of symptoms sometimes found in people with mitral valve prolapse has been called "mitral valve prolapse syndrome," and includes:
The exact relationship is between these symptoms and the valve problem is not clear. Some of the findings may be coincidental.
When mitral regurgitation occurs, symptoms may be related to the leaking, particularly when severe.
lists: Chest pain (not caused by coronary artery disease or a heart attack)
Sensation of feeling the heart beat (palpitations)
Shortness of breath with activity or when lying flat (orthopnea)

title: Aortic dissection
paragraphs: In most cases, the symptoms begin suddenly, and include severe chest pain. The pain may feel like a heart attack.
Symptoms are caused by a decrease of blood flowing to the rest of the body, and can include:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Pain can be described as sharp, stabbing, tearing, or ripping.
It is felt below the breast bone, and then moves under the shoulder blades or to the back.
Pain can move to the shoulder, neck, arm, jaw, abdomen, or hips.
The pain changes position, often moving to the arms and legs as the aortic dissection gets worse.
Anxiety and a feeling of doom
Shortness of breath and trouble breathing when lying flat (orthopnea)
Swallowing difficulties from pressure on the esophagus

title: Pericarditis
paragraphs: Chest pain is almost always present. The pain:
You may have fever, chills, or sweating if the condition is caused by an infection.
Other symptoms may include:
lists: May be felt in the neck, shoulder, back, or abdomen
Often increases with deep breathing and lying flat, and may increase with coughing and swallowing
Is often relieved by sitting up and leaning or bending forward

title: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT)
paragraphs: Symptoms most often start and stop suddenly. They can last for a few minutes or several hours. Symptoms may include:
Other symptoms that can occur with this condition include:
lists: Palpitations (a sensation of feeling the heartbeat), often with an irregular or fast rate (racing)

title: Atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter
paragraphs: You may not be aware that your heart is not beating in a normal pattern. When symptoms are present, they may include one or more of the following:
lists: Pulse that feels rapid, racing, pounding or thumping, fluttering, irregular, or too slow.
Sensation of feeling the heart beat (palpitations).
Chest pain or pressure, which may be a sign of a heart attack. Call 911 or the local emergency number right away if you have chest pain or pressure.

title: Cardiogenic shock
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists: Loss of alertness and ability to concentrate
Skin that feels cool to the touch
Pale skin color or blotchy skin

title: Multifocal atrial tachycardia
paragraphs: Some people may have no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they can include:
Other symptoms that can occur with this disease:
lists: Sensation of feeling the heart is beating irregularly or too fast (palpitations)
Weight loss and failure to thrive in infants

title: Ventricular tachycardia
paragraphs: You may have symptoms if the heart rate during a VT episode is very fast or lasts longer than a few seconds. Symptoms may include:
Symptoms may start and stop suddenly. In some cases, there are no symptoms.
lists: Sensation of feeling the heart beat (palpitations)

title: Restrictive cardiomyopathy
paragraphs: Symptoms of heart failure are most common. These symptoms often develop slowly over time. However, symptoms sometimes start very suddenly and are severe.
Common symptoms are:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Breathing problems that occur at night, with activity or when lying flat
Swelling of the feet and ankles
Need to urinate at night (in adults)

title: Coarctation of the aorta
paragraphs: Symptoms depend on how much blood can flow through the artery. Other heart defects may also play a role.

About half of newborns with this problem will have symptoms in the first few days of life. These can include breathing fast, problems eating, increased irritability, and increased sleepiness or becoming poorly responsive. In severe cases, the infant may develop heart failure and shock.
In milder cases, symptoms may not develop until the child has reached adolescence. Symptoms can include:
There may also be no symptoms.

title: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
paragraphs: Some people with the condition may have no symptoms. They may first find out they have the problem during a routine medical exam.

In many young adults, the first symptom of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is sudden collapse and possible death. This can be caused by highly abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias). It may also be due to a blockage that prevents the outflow of blood from the heart to the rest of the body.
Common symptoms include:
lists: Lightheadedness, especially with or after activity or exercise
Sensation of feeling the heart beat fast or irregularly (palpitations)
Shortness of breath with activity or after lying down (or being asleep for a while)

title: Cardiac amyloidosis
paragraphs: Some people may have no symptoms. When present, symptoms may include:
lists: Swelling of the abdomen, legs, ankles, or other part of the body

title: Cardiac tamponade
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
Other symptoms that may occur with this disorder:
lists: Sharp chest pain that is felt in the neck, shoulder, back, or abdomen
Chest pain that gets worse with deep breathing or coughing
Discomfort, sometimes relieved by sitting upright or leaning forward
Swelling of the legs or abdomen

title: Heart attack
paragraphs: A heart attack is a medical emergency. If you have symptoms of a heart attack, call 911 or your local emergency number right away.
Chest pain is the most common symptom of a heart attack.
The pain can be severe or mild. It can feel like:

The pain most often lasts longer than 20 minutes. Rest and a medicine to relax the blood vessels (called nitroglycerin) may not completely relieve the pain of a heart attack. Symptoms may also go away and come back.
Other symptoms of a heart attack can include:

Some people (including older adults, people with diabetes, and women) may have little or no chest pain. Or, they may have atypical symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and weakness. A "silent heart attack," which can also occur, is a heart attack with no symptoms.
lists: DO NOT try to drive yourself to the hospital.
DO NOT WAIT. You are at greatest risk for sudden death in the early hours of a heart attack.
You may feel the pain in only one part of your body OR
Pain may move from your chest to your arms, shoulder, neck, teeth, jaw, belly area, or back
A tight band around the chest
Something heavy sitting on your chest
Palpitations (feeling like your heart is beating too fast or irregularly)
Sweating, which may be very heavy

title: Stable angina
paragraphs: Symptoms of stable angina are most often predictable. This means that the same amount of exercise or activity may cause your angina to occur. Your angina should improve or go away when you stop or slow down the exercise.

The most common symptom is chest pain that occurs behind the breastbone or slightly to the left of it. The pain of stable angina most often begins slowly and gets worse over the next few minutes before going away.
Typically, the chest pain feels like tightness, heavy pressure, squeezing, or a crushing feeling. It may spread to the:
Some people say the pain feels like gas or indigestion.
Less common symptoms of angina may include:
Pain from stable angina:
Angina attacks can occur at any time during the day. Often, they occur between 6 a.m. and noon.
lists: Most often comes on with activity or stress
Lasts an average of 1 to 15 minutes
Is relieved with rest or a medicine called nitroglycerin

title: Superficial thrombophlebitis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include any of the following:
lists: Skin redness, inflammation, tenderness, or pain along a vein just below the skin

title: Phlegmasia cerulea dolens
paragraphs: Severe pain, rapid swelling, and bluish-skin coloring affect the area below the blocked vein.

title: Unstable angina
paragraphs: Symptoms of angina may include:
With stable angina, the chest pain or other symptoms only occur with a certain amount of activity or stress. The pain does not occur more often or get worse over time.
Unstable angina is chest pain that is sudden and often gets worse over a short period of time. You may be developing unstable angina if your chest pain:
Unstable angina is a warning sign that a heart attack may happen soon and needs to be treated right away. Contact your health care provider if you have any type of chest pain.
lists: Chest pain that you may also feel in the shoulder, arm, jaw, neck, back, or other area
Discomfort that feels like tightness, squeezing, crushing, burning, choking, or aching
Discomfort that occurs at rest and does not easily go away when you take medicine
Starts to feel different, is more severe, comes more often, or occurs with less activity or while you are at rest
Occurs without cause (for example, while you are asleep or sitting quietly)
Does not respond well to a medicine called nitroglycerin (especially if this medicine worked to relieve chest pain in the past)
Occurs with a drop in blood pressure or shortness of breath

title: Myocardial contusion
paragraphs: A severe myocardial contusion may lead to signs and symptoms of a heart attack.
Symptoms can include:
lists: Pain in the front of the ribs or breastbone
Feeling that your heart is racing

title: Venous insufficiency
paragraphs: Pain or other symptoms include:
Skin changes in the legs include:
lists: Dull aching, heaviness, or cramping in legs
Pain that gets worse when standing
Pain that gets better when legs are raised
Irritated or cracked skin if you scratch it
Red or swollen, crusted, or weepy skin (stasis dermatitis)
Thickening and hardening of the skin on the legs and ankles (lipodermatosclerosis)
Wound or ulcer that is slow to heal on the legs or ankles

title: Renovascular hypertension
paragraphs: People with renovascular hypertension may have a history of very high blood pressure that is hard to bring down with medicines.
Symptoms of renovascular hypertension include:
If you have a dangerous form of high blood pressure called malignant hypertension, symptomsÂ canÂ include:
lists: High blood pressure at a young age
High blood pressure that suddenly gets worse or is hard to control
Kidneys that are not working well (this can start suddenly)
Narrowing of other arteries in the body, such as to the legs, the brain, the eyes and elsewhere
Sudden buildup of fluid in the air sacs of the lungs (pulmonary edema)

title: Peptic ulcer
paragraphs: Small ulcers may not cause any symptoms and may heal without treatment. Some ulcers can cause serious bleeding.
Abdominal pain (often in the upper mid-abdomen) is a common symptom. The pain can differ from person to person. Some people have no pain.
Pain occurs:
Other symptoms include:
lists: At night and wakes you up
When you feel an empty stomach, often 1 to 3 hours after a meal
Feeling of fullness and problems drinking as much fluid as usual

title: Esophageal stricture - benign
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:

title: Lower esophageal ring
paragraphs: For most people, a lower esophageal ring does not cause symptoms.
The most common symptom is the feeling that food (especially solid food) is stuck in the lower neck or under the breastbone (sternum).

title: Whipple disease
paragraphs: Symptoms most often start slowly. Joint pain is the most common early symptom. Symptoms of gastrointestinal (GI) infection often occur several years later. Other symptoms may include:
lists: Darkening of skin in light-exposed areas of the body
Joint pain in the ankles, knees, elbows, fingers, or other areas

title: Jaundice
paragraphs: Jaundice may appear suddenly or develop slowly over time. Symptoms of jaundice commonly include:

Note: If your skin is yellow and the whites of your eyes are not yellow, you may not have jaundice. Your skin can turn a yellow-to-orange color if you eat a lot of beta carotene, the orange pigment in carrots.
Other symptoms depend on the disorder causing the jaundice:
lists: Yellow skin and the white part of the eyes (sclera) -- when jaundice is more severe, these areas may look brown
Cancers may produce no symptoms, or there may be fatigue, weight loss, or other symptoms.
Hepatitis may produce nausea, vomiting, fatigue, or other symptoms.

title: Amebic liver abscess
paragraphs: There are usually no symptoms of intestinal infection. But people with amebic liver abscess do have symptoms, including:
lists: Abdominal pain, more so in the right, upper part of the abdomen; pain is intense, continuous or stabbing
Diarrhea, non-bloody (in only one-third of people with amebic liver abscess)
General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise)

Jaundice
   (yellowing of the skin, mucous membranes, or eyes)

title: Abscess - abdomen or pelvis
paragraphs: Pain or discomfort in the belly that does not go away is a common symptom. This pain:
Depending on where the abscess is located, you may have:
Other symptoms of an abdominal abscess may be a lot like symptoms of having the flu. You may have:
lists: May be found only in one area of your belly or over most of your belly
Pain in your chest or shoulder
Lack of appetite and possible weight loss

title: Hepatic ischemia
paragraphs: The person may have an altered mental status due to reduced blood flow to the brain. Other symptoms may include:
Damage to the liver cells most often does not cause symptoms until it affects liver function.
Blood clots in the liver's main artery may cause abdominal pain.
lists: Discomfort in the right upper quadrant of your abdomen

title: Cholestasis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
lists: Pain in the right upper part of the abdomen

title: Hepatitis D (Delta agent)
paragraphs: Hepatitis D may make the symptoms of hepatitis B worse.
Symptoms may include:

title: Chronic cholecystitis
paragraphs: Acute cholecystitis is a painful condition that may lead to chronic cholecystitis. It is not clear whether chronic cholecystitis causes any symptoms.
Symptoms of acute cholecystitis can include:
lists: Sharp, cramping, or dull pain in upper right or upper middle of your belly
Pain that spreads to your back or below your right shoulder blade
Yellowing of skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)

title: Bile duct stricture
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists:
Abdominal pain
  on the upper right side of belly

title: Chronic pancreatitis
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
ABDOMINAL PAIN
DIGESTIVE PROBLEMS
lists: May last from hours to days; over time, may always be present
May get worse from drinking alcohol
May also be felt in the back as if it is boring through the abdomen
Chronic weight loss, even when eating habits and amounts are normal.
Chronic pancreatitis can lead to pancreatic cancer.

title: Small bowel bacterial overgrowth
paragraphs: The most common symptoms are:
Other symptoms may include:

title: Stomach cancer
paragraphs: Symptoms of stomach cancer may include any of the following:
lists: Abdominal fullness or pain, which may occur after a small meal
Difficulty swallowing, which becomes worse over time

title: Campylobacter infection
paragraphs: Symptoms start 2Â to 4 days after being exposed to the bacteria. They often last a week, and may include:

title: Drug-induced liver injury
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:

title: VIPoma
paragraphs: Symptoms of VIPoma may include any of the following:
lists: Diarrhea (watery, and often in large amounts)
Flushing or redness of the face
Muscle cramps due to low blood potassium (hypokalemia)

title: Fecal impaction
paragraphs: Common symptoms include:
Other possible symptoms include:
lists: Leakage of liquid or sudden episodes of watery diarrhea in someone who has chronic (long-term) constipation
Straining when trying to pass stools
Bladder pressure or loss of bladder control
Rapid heartbeat or lightheadedness from straining to pass stool

title: Esophageal perforation
paragraphs: The main symptom is pain when the problem first occurs.
A perforation in the middle or lower most part of the esophagus may cause:

title: Celiac disease â sprue
paragraphs: The symptoms of celiac disease can be different from person to person. This can make diagnosis difficult. For example, one person may have constipation, a second may have diarrhea, and a third may have no problem with stools.
Gastrointestinal symptoms include:
Other problems that can develop over time because the intestines do not absorb key nutrients include:
Children with celiac disease may have:
lists: Abdominal pain, bloating, gas, or indigestion
Decreased appetite (may also be increased or unchanged)
Diarrhea, either constant or off and on
Lactose intolerance (common when the person is diagnosed, often goes away after treatment)
Stools that are foul smelling, oily, or stick to the toilet when flushed
Unexplained weight loss (although people can be overweight or normal weight)
Itchy skin with a rash (dermatitis herpetiformis)
Tingling or numbness in the hands or feet
Defects in the tooth enamel and changes in tooth color
Diarrhea, constipation, fatty or foul-smelling stools, nausea, or vomiting
Slowed growth and shorter than normal height for their age

title: Meckel diverticulum
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
Symptoms often occur during the first few years of life. However, they may not start until adulthood.
lists: Pain in the abdomen that can be mild or severe

title: Gastrointestinal perforation
paragraphs: Perforation of the intestine or other organs causes the contents to leak into the abdomen. This causes a severe infection called peritonitis.
Symptoms may include:

title: Pancreatic cancer
paragraphs: A tumor (cancer) in the pancreas may grow without any symptoms at first. This means the cancer is often advanced when it is first found.
Symptoms of pancreatic cancer include:
lists: Sudden increase in blood sugar level (diabetes)
Jaundice (a yellow color in the skin, mucous membranes, or white part of the eyes) and itching of the skin
Loss of appetite and weight loss
Pain or discomfort in the upper part of the belly or abdomen

title: Short bowel syndrome
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:

title: Angiodysplasia of the colon
paragraphs: The symptoms vary.
Older people may have symptoms such as:
They may not have noticeable bleeding directly from the colon.
Other people may have bouts of mild or severe bleeding in which bright red or black blood comes from the rectum.
There is no pain associated with angiodysplasia.
lists: Shortness of breath due to anemia

title: Hepatic vein obstruction (Budd-Chiari)
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists: Abdominal swelling or stretching due to fluid in the abdomen
Pain in the right upper abdomen

title: Dubin-Johnson syndrome
paragraphs: Mild jaundice, which may not appear until puberty or adulthood, is most often the only symptom of DJS.

title: Hepatic hemangioma
paragraphs: Some hemangiomas may cause bleeding or interfere with organ function. Most do not produce symptoms. In rare cases, the hemangioma may rupture.

title: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
paragraphs: Symptoms of PJS are:
lists: Brownish or bluish-gray spots on the lips, gums, inner lining of the mouth, and skin
Cramping pain in the belly area
Dark freckles on and around the lips of a child
Blood in the stool that can be seen with the naked eye (sometimes)

title: Autoimmune hepatitis
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
Absence of menstruation (amenorrhea) may also be a symptom.
lists: General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling (malaise)

title: Irritable bowel syndrome
paragraphs: IBS symptoms vary from person to person, and range from mild to severe. Most people have mild symptoms. You are said to have IBS when symptoms are present for at least 3 days a month for a period of 3 months or more.
The main symptoms include:
Pain and other symptoms will often be reduced or go away after a bowel movement. Symptoms may flare up when there is a change in the frequency of your bowel movements.
People with IBS may go back and forth between having constipation and diarrhea or have or mostly have one or the other.
The symptoms may get worse for a few weeks or a month, and then decrease for a while. In other cases, symptoms are present most of the time.
You may also lose your appetite if you have IBS. However, blood in stools and unintentional weight loss are not a part of IBS.
lists: Change in bowel habits. You canÂ have either diarrhea (IBS-D), or constipation (IBS-C).
If you have IBS with diarrhea, you will have frequent, loose, watery stools. You may have an urgent need to have a bowel movement, which may be hard to control.

If you have IBS with constipation, you will have a hard time passing stool, as well as fewer bowel movements. You may need to strain with a bowel movement and have cramps. Often, only a small amount or no stool at all will pass.

title: Pancreas divisum
paragraphs: Many people do not have any symptoms. If you have pancreatitis, symptoms include:
lists: Abdominal pain, most often in the upper abdomen that may be felt in the back

title: Toxic megacolon
paragraphs: The rapid widening of the colon may cause the following symptoms to occur over a short period of time:

title: Crohn disease
paragraphs: Symptoms depend on the part of the digestive tract involved. Symptoms range from mild to severe, and can come and go, with periods of flare-ups.
The main symptoms of Crohn disease are:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Crampy pain in the abdomen (belly area).
Loss of appetite and weight loss.
Feeling that you need to pass stools, even though your bowels are already empty (tenesmus). It may involve straining, pain, and cramping.
Watery diarrhea, which may be bloody.
Sores or swelling in the eyes
Draining of pus, mucus, or stools from around the rectum or anus (caused by something called a fistula)
Tender, red bumps (nodules) under the skin, which may turn into skin ulcers

title: Ulcerative colitis
paragraphs: The symptoms can be more or less severe. They may start slowly or suddenly. Half of people only have mild symptoms. Others have more severe attacks that occur more often. Many factors can lead to attacks.
Symptoms may include:
Children's growth may slow.
Other symptoms that may occur with ulcerative colitis include the following:
lists: Pain in the abdomen (belly area) and cramping.
A gurgling or splashing sound heard over the intestine.
Blood and possibly pus in the stools.
Diarrhea, from only a few episodes to very often.
Feeling that you need to pass stools, even though your bowels are already empty (tenesmus). It may involve straining, pain, and cramping.

title: Viral gastroenteritis (stomach flu)
paragraphs: Symptoms most often appear within 4 to 48 hours after contact with the virus. Common symptoms include:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Joint stiffness or muscle pain Â Â Â

title: Intestinal pseudo-obstruction
paragraphs: Symptoms include:

title: Bacterial gastroenteritis
paragraphs: Symptoms depend on the type of bacteria that caused the sickness. All types of food poisoning cause diarrhea. Other symptoms include:

title: Cirrhosis
paragraphs: There may be no symptoms, or symptoms may come on slowly, depending on how well the liver is working. Often, it is discovered by chance when an abdominal ultrasound exam is done or blood is drawn for another reason.
Early symptoms include:
As liver function worsens, symptoms may include:
lists: Small, red spider-like blood vessels on the skin
Fluid buildup in the legs (edema) and in the abdomen (ascites)
Yellow color in the skin, mucous membranes, or eyes (jaundice)
Redness on the palms of the hands
In men, impotence, shrinking of the testicles, and breast swelling
Easy bruising and abnormal bleeding, most often from swollen veins in the digestive tract
Bleeding from upper or lower gastrointestinal tract

title: Appendicitis
paragraphs: The symptoms of appendicitis can vary. It can be hard to detect appendicitis in young children, older people, and women of childbearing age.

The first symptom is often pain around the belly button or mid upper abdomen. Pain may be minor at first, but becomes more sharp and severe. You may also have a loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, and a low-grade fever.

The pain tends to move into the right lower part of your belly. The pain tends to focus at a spot directly above the appendix called McBurney point. This most often occurs 12 to 24 hours after the illness starts.
Your pain may be worse when you walk, cough, or make sudden movements. Later symptoms include:

title: Diverticulitis
paragraphs: People with diverticulosis often have no symptoms, but they may have bloating and cramping in the lower part of the belly. Rarely, they may notice blood in their stool or on toilet paper.
Symptoms of diverticulitis are more severe and often start suddenly, but they may become worse over a few days. They include:
lists: Pain or discomfort, usually in the left lower part of the abdomen
Not feeling hungry and not eating

title: Pseudomembranous colitis
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists: Urge to have a bowel movement
Watery diarrhea (often 5 to 10 times per day)

title: Intestinal obstruction and Ileus
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:

title: Pyogenic liver abscess
paragraphs: Symptoms of liver abscess may include:
lists: Pain in the right upper abdomen (more common) or throughout the abdomen (less common)

title: Colorectal cancer
paragraphs: Many cases of colon cancer have no symptoms. If there are symptoms, the following may indicate colon cancer:
lists: Abdominal pain and tenderness in the lower abdomen
Diarrhea, constipation, or other change in bowel habits
Weight loss with no known reason

title: Bile duct obstruction
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:
lists: Abdominal pain in the upper right side

title: Acute cholecystitis
paragraphs: The main symptom is pain in the upper right side or upper middle of your belly that usually lasts at least 30 minutes. You may feel:
Other symptoms that may occur include:
lists: Pain that spreads to your back or below your right shoulder blade
Yellowing of skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)

title: Gastroesophageal reflux disease
paragraphs: Common symptoms of GERD include:
Less common symptoms are:
Symptoms may get worse when you bend over or lie down, or after you eat. Symptoms may also be worse at night.
lists: Feeling that food is stuck behind the breastbone
Heartburn or a burning pain in the chest

title: Colorectal polyps
paragraphs: Polyps usually do not have symptoms. When present, symptoms may include:
lists: Fatigue caused by losing blood over time

title: Achalasia
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
lists: Chest pain, which may increase after eating, or may be felt as pain in the back, neck, and arms

title: Bleeding esophageal varices
paragraphs: People with chronic liver disease and esophageal varices may have no symptoms.
If there is only a small amount of bleeding, the only symptom may be dark or black streaks in the stools.
If larger amounts of bleeding occur, symptoms may include:

title: Mallory-Weiss tear
paragraphs: Symptoms may include:

title: Pancreatic abscess
paragraphs: Symptoms include:

title: Pancreatic pseudocyst
paragraphs: Symptoms can occur within days to months after an attack of pancreatitis. They include:
lists: Constant pain or deep ache in the abdomen, which may also be felt in the back

title: Gallstones
paragraphs: Many people with gallstones do not have any symptoms. These are often found during a routine x-ray, abdominal surgery, or other medical procedure.

However, if a large stone blocks a tube or duct that drains the gallbladder, you may have a cramping pain in the middle to right upper abdomen. This is known as biliary colic. The pain goes away if the stone passes into the first part of the small intestine.
Symptoms that may occur include:
Other symptoms may include:
lists: Pain in the right upper or middle upper abdomen for at least 30 minutes. The pain may be constant or cramping. It can feel sharp or dull.
Yellowing of skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice).

title: Choledocholithiasis
paragraphs: Often, there are no symptoms unless the stone blocks the common bile duct. Symptoms may include:
lists: Pain in the right upper or middle upper abdomen for at least 30 minutes. The pain may be constant and intense. It can be mild or severe.
Yellowing of skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice).

title: Tropical sprue
paragraphs: Symptoms include:
Symptoms may not appear for up to 10 years after leaving the tropics.
lists: Diarrhea, worse on a high-fat diet

title: Lactose intolerance
paragraphs: Symptoms often occur 30 minutes to 2 hours after having milk products. Symptoms may be worse when you consume large amounts.
Symptoms include:

title: Liver metastases
paragraphs: In some cases, there are no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they may include:
lists: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes)
Pain, often in the upper right part of the abdomen

title: Hepatitis A
paragraphs: Symptoms most often show up 2 to 6 weeks after being exposed to the hepatitis A virus. They are most often mild, but may last for up to several months, especially in adults.
Symptoms include:

title: Hepatitis B
paragraphs: After you first become infected with the HBV:
Symptoms of hepatitis B may not appear for up to 6 months after the time of infection. Early symptoms include:
Symptoms will go away in a few weeks to months if your body is able to fight off the infection. Some people never get rid of the HBV. This is called chronic hepatitis B.
People with chronic hepatitis may not have symptoms and may not know they are infected. Over time, they may develop symptoms of liver damage and cirrhosis of the liver.
You can spread the HBV to other people, even if you have no symptoms.
lists: You may feel sick for a period of days or weeks.
You may become very ill very quickly (called fulminant hepatitis).

title: Liver cancer - hepatocellular carcinoma
paragraphs: Symptoms of liver cancer may include any of the following:
lists: Abdominal pain or tenderness, especially in the upper-right part
Enlarged abdomen due to fluid in the abdomen (ascites)

title: Alcoholic liver disease
paragraphs: There may be no symptoms, or symptoms may come on slowly. This depends on how well the liver is working. Symptoms tend to be worse after a period of heavy drinking.
Early symptoms include:
As liver function worsens, symptoms may include:
lists: Small, red spider-like blood vessels on the skin
Fluid buildup of the legs (edema) and in the abdomen (ascites)
Yellow color in the skin, mucous membranes, or eyes (jaundice)
